title: About
text: About this site

title: Data Analysis for the Group Research Project - BIO00088H
text:
Data Analysis for the Group Research Project (BIO00088H) compromises six workshops covering computational skills needed in your project. Three of these are core and taken by everyone and three are specific to your project type.
The project types are:







Project
Data Strand




Stem Cells, Jillian Barlow
â€™omics, Emma Rand


Developmental Biology, Betsy Pownal
â€™omics, Emma Rand


Microbial Ecology, Kelly Redeker
â€™omics, Emma Rand


Structural Biochemistry, Michael Plevin
molecular-structure, Jon Agirre


Neuroscience, Sean Sweeney
image-analysis, Richard Bingham


xxxxxxxxxxxx, Richard Maguire
image-analysis, Richard Bingham



The data analysis workshops are:
|â€”â€”â€“|â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€“| | Week 1 | Core 1 | | Week 2 | Core 2 | | Week 3 | omics/structure/images 1 | | Week 4 | omics/structure/images 2 | | Week 5 | omics/structure/images 3 | | Week 6 | Core 3 |


Students who successfully complete this module will be able to

use appropriate computational techniques to reproducibly process, analyse and visualise data and generate scientific reports based on project work.




All material is on the VLE so why is this site useful? This site collects everything together in a searchable way. The search icon is on the top right.

title: Core Data Analysis for Group Project
text:
Overview You are either an integrated masters student doing 88H Group Project or a MSc Bioinformatics student doing 70M


Note no R coding (too early for MSc BIN 70M who share the core and omics teaching)
Before - Optional revision: What they forgot to teach you about computers: operating systems, file systems, file types, working directories and paths

Why reproducibility (BIO00058M-Data-science-2020/slides/03_repro_and_intro_to_rmarkdown)

Workshop

Project organisation: folders, files
Project oriented workflow
Naming things
File formats
Data management

google drive: https://www.york.ac.uk/it-services/services/drive/#tab-6
documenting
organisation within files

Data files. Similarities and differences

Sequences data
Image data
Structure data.

Keeping notes
Readme
Reference managers: Zotero

After



Before Possibly: Code formatting and style, ðŸ˜Ž Cool code Tips, Code â€˜algorithmically.â€™, Writing functions (R and python??) (BIO00058M-Data-science-2020/slides/03_repro_and_intro_to_rmarkdown)
Workshop
After



Before (BIO00058M-Data-science-2020/slides/03_repro_and_intro_to_rmarkdown and BIO00058M-Data-science-2020/slides/04_advanced_rmarkdown.html) Literate programming What is quarto markdown basics: text, code chunks, headings yaml automatic numbering of figures and tables cross references special characters citations
Workshop
practice doing the above with your project and data
After
